title: A Hypercat-enabled Semantic Internet of Things Data Hub
segmentation: Hello everyone, my name is Elias Thomas.

I'm research fellow at the University of Huddersfield and today I'll present them hyper, got enabled semantic Internet of Things data Hub and this is a joint work between the University of Huddersfield and British welcomes thanks.

How we translate data.

Directions.
So the motivation for this work is actually this small city wave that everyone is talking about.
And by Smart City we.

We mean the use of technology in order to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of how we run our cities, provide better city services, and essentially improve the quality of the people that live in the cities.
Our point of view is that in order to have successful smart city solutions, we need to.

All other iodi and smart cities projects include the city of Barcelona and also MK Smart.

So the main argument for this work is if we want smart city solutions, we need to combine this data in order to improve interoperability.
So the probably the best way to do that is to add semantics to the data that we have.
And provide a better quality data.
So the aim of this work is actually take the existing system and develop an semantic layer on top of the existing system.

There was a Restful API that provided data in either Jason or XML format and also there was a Hypercard catalog which the standard indicates that it's.
It should be available in Jason format, So what we did.
First, of course, because we are in Semantic Web conference, we started with ontology.
Now once we developed the ontology, we were able to translate the data that we had in the relational database and actually provide.
A restful API that gives the information in RDF format.
Besides that, we also proposed an.

An alternative for now the RDF alternative for these Hyper Cut catalog standard and we show how it can be used by extending the hyperbolic RDF version of the core and also the ontology for this system.
Besides that we developed a sparkle endpoint and the way we did it is instead.
Well, instead of storing a triple store, we dynamically translate sparkle queries from sparkle to SQL.
We query the relational database and then map back the results as sparkle results.
Now, by having this sparkle endpoint, we eventually were able to link the information that we had stored in the system with the rest of the world with the link open data cloud.

So if we have a weather feed then the sensor the sensor feed will have several sensor streams, one stream for.

What about some use cases that would actually use this system, so the first use case is the simplified project.
It's a traffic management project with the aim of the project is to reduce traffic within the Manchester City and improve the air quality.

Owl our target was so there were many components with many people working with that, but our target was to provide a higher level of data integration, which means to provide a consistent way of combining real time data with historical urban data.
And the idea was that once we enrich with semantically enriched data, we can give it to the traffic management system.
Anet can uniquely identify all the resources in our world.
So the strategies would solve problems that are coming from unexpected conditions.
In case, let's say there is an accident.
Now, the way the system works is that raw data are coming from transport or environmental sources to the data hub.
The data hub integrates them and provide them to the planner.
Now the planner will come up with some strategies with a plan that will allow us to decongest the area quicker.
So we've run some simulations and simulations so showed that on average we have the idea is decongestive 20.
Percent faster and the tailpipe emissions are reduced by 25%.
Now the second use case is the city concierge use case.
It's actually a use case of the City Verb project, which is again a Manchester based project.
Is an IoT demonstrator project.
And the idea is to increase walking and cycling throughout the city as a travel mode without within the Greater Manchester area.
And the aim of this use case is to develop a user interface throughout the city.
That will somehow integrate the transportation with the visitor service.

So what we want to do is to improve the way people navigate around the city and we want to provide both digital solutions so that people could get navigation in their smartphone or some or even on the way physical way funding assets that will be installed throughout the city.
So at this point we have established that the data hub is providing the infrastructure and the functionality that we need in order to enable this use case.
So this is just an example that by the end of this project people will be able to navigate through.
There are mobile phones or the physical wave founding assets and this is a map of Monster or where these assets are expected to be.
Installed.
Well, future work.
Our part is actually we're focusing on more semantic enrichment of the existing system and the way to do that is to work on locations.

So we are aiming to support Geo SPARQL queries, not just partial queries, and also work on the existing locations within the system in order to derive more information through spatial temporal reasoning.
So thank you.
And your questions.
